---
title: Når mor blir et dyr. Om transformerte mødre i to skandinaviske bildebøker for
  barn
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-WZQELJSB" class="csl-bib-container">

<div id="csl-bib-meta-WZQELJSB" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-WZQELJSB" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Vie and Sommervold explore how mothers are depicted as animals in two Scandinavian children's picture books. They look at Pija Lindenbaum’s "När Åkes mamma glömde bort" and Kari Saanum and Gry Moursund’s "Pinnsvinmamma." The authors find that when mothers transform into animals, it reflects the playful imagination of the children. These transformations show mothers losing their usual roles and abilities, which changes the power dynamics between mother and child. The study also questions whether these books present a traditional view of mothers as safe and comforting or challenge typical ideas of motherhood. This research helps us understand how children's literature can influence perceptions of family roles and relationships.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-WZQELJSB" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Scandinavian Picturebooks, Mother Figures, Animal Transformations, Child Play, Normative Motherhood
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-WZQELJSB" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This article examines the animal nature of the mother figures in the two Scandinavian picturebooks Pija Lindenbaum’s När Åkes mamma glömde bort (When Owen’s Mom Breathed Fire, 2005) and Kari Saanum and Gry Moursund’s Pinnsvinmamma (Hedgehog Mom, 2006). The main aim is to study how the mother’s role is portrayed in the two picturebooks when  she  is  transformed  into  an  animal,  and  the  functions  of  animal  transformations. The article shows that the two mothers’ transformations can be understood as journeys in the child characters’ playful mind, where the  mentally  unavailable  mothers  are  situated  in  the  “magical  circle”  of  play. When being transformed, the mother figures lose their original body and mothering abilities, and the power balance between mother and child changes.  Finally,  we  discuss  whether  the  two  picturebooks  represent  a  traditional view of the mother figure as safe and reconciling, or whether they challenge  the  limits  of  normative  motherhood.  The  theoretical  framework  includes picturebook theory, transformation theory and mindscape theory
  </article>
